SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the article best explains why stunt performers are willing to do such a dangerous job?

A.Choice: “For the stunt performers, this is the day's work.” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “But performers enjoy the thrill of their work and push themselves hard to do more spectacular stunts.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “They work hard to make it look as if someone else is doing the stunt.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “This means filming in remote places such as deserts, jungles, and mountains.” (paragraph 12)

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Based on paragraphs 10 through 12, what must stunt actors do to train for their jobs?

A.Choice: They must work to get their bodies ready for action and in good shape.

B.Choice: They must live in far off places.

C.Choice: They must learn to be either a gymnast or a martial artist.

D.Choice: They must become specialists in horse riding, working with explosives, and scuba diving.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Based on the article, why do some stunt actors spend long periods of time away from home?

A.Choice: They need to live in different parts of the world to be able to help the actors.

B.Choice: They need to hike and climb in deserts, jungles, and mountains to help them stay in shape.

C.Choice: They need to travel to the different places where movies and television shows are filmed.

D.Choice: They need to go to different places to learn new skills from experts.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: Based on the article, music helps circus performers by

A.Choice: calming their fears when they are in front of an audience

B.Choice: reminding them of home when they are performing in new places

C.Choice: letting them know when to begin and end parts of their shows

D.Choice: allowing them to relax during difficult stunts

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: How do paragraphs 15 through 19 support the author's main points?

A.Choice: They show that stunt performing has too many dangers.

B.Choice: They give details about how stunt performers train their bodies.

C.Choice: They show how stunt performing is something everyone can do.

D.Choice: They give details about the types of danger stunt performers face.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which paragraph best supports a main idea of the article?

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: What does paragraph 3 reveal about Ms. Snoops?

D.Choice: She wishes Ali were her daughter.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Which detail best reveals what Ali wants to be when she grows up?

A.Choice: Ali thinks of things starting with 'M' to try to help Ms. Snoops remember.

B.Choice: Ali collects old objects to show to Ms. Snoops.

C.Choice: Ms. Snoops explains to Ali that making things up is what writers do.

D.Choice: Ms. Snoops thanks Ali for bringing her treasures.

SubTopics: Explain the meaning of simple similes and metaphors (e.g., as pretty as a picture) in context.
Content: According to the story, what does the phrase “fill in the holes myself” (paragraph 16) mean?

A.Choice: rely on memory to finish a true story

B.Choice: find evidence for the most likely explanation for a story

C.Choice: ask someone questions to figure out the whole story

D.Choice: create details to complete an unfinished story

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Which sentence expresses something important that Ali and Ms. Snoops have in common?

A.Choice: They both like old-fashioned fruit preserves.

B.Choice: The icy-blue stone is a mystery to both of them.

C.Choice: They both enjoy making up stories.

D.Choice: Shirley the doll means a lot to both of them.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which theme is best supported by paragraph 21?

A.Choice: Childhood toys should be kept forever.

B.Choice: Important lessons can be learned from the past.

C.Choice: Nothing brings more joy than to talk with a friend.

D.Choice: Something that seems worthless may be special to someone.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: “Ms. Snoops went to her desk and brought back a sheet of paper marked with a big handwritten 'M.'” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “Maybe you were thinking of baking your delicious orange muffins. You haven't made those in a while.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “I would bet dollars to doughnuts this was one of Pug's stones. He collected unusual ones.” (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: “ All these treasures you've shown me have brought back my memories, and I am so grateful.” (paragraph 24)

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: In paragraph 2, the details about Lary Greene are important because they suggest why

B.Choice: his book is full of good ideas for running

D.Choice: his advice about training can be trusted

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: Based on the article, what is the main reason it is helpful to join a team or a club?

A.Choice: You can have fun running with people.

B.Choice: You can improve by working with a coach.

C.Choice: You can learn to change your time goals.

D.Choice: You can learn to run far without getting tired.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Why is the text box “Fun Run” included in the article?

A.Choice: It provides ideas for training that add to suggestions given in the article.

B.Choice: It gives an opinion about training that is different from the rest of the article.

C.Choice: It suggests that a silly approach to running is better than the article's serious approach.

D.Choice: It provides evidence to support the article's claim that people can become better runners.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 1.
:box:As your body becomes more conditioned to the exercise, you'll get the endurance to go even farther and faster.
Which paragraph best supports this claim?

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: Based on paragraph 6, what does it mean to run “efficiently”?

A.Choice: to stretch and cool down correctly

B.Choice: to use correct speed and form

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence best expresses the main idea of the article?

A.Choice: “If your school participates in the President's Challenge, chances are you have taken the Physical Fitness Test.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “But to perform your best in the mile run, and to feel good doing it, you really need to prepare properly,' says Larry Greene.” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “To train for a mile run, start by running a short distance, such as one-quarter mile.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “'Don't push yourself when running becomes painful,' Greene says.” (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Based on information in the text box “First Place Finish!” what can the reader conclude about racing?

A.Choice: Running in races can encourage people to work hard.

B.Choice: Competing in races is something every runner must try.

C.Choice: Training three days a week is necessary to win races.

D.Choice: Winning championship races requires joining a program.

SubTopics: Integrate information from two texts on the same topic in order to write or speak about the subject knowledgeably.

Content: Both “[Excerpt from] Double Dutch: A Celebration of Jump Rope, Rhyme, and Sisterhood” and “[Excerpt from] Its Our World, Too!” are about a young person's solution to a problem. Describe a problem each one faces. How are the ways they solve their problems similar and different? Use details from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• describe a problem each young person faces
• explain the similarities and differences of their solutions to the problems
• use details from both articles to support your response
